thread.title: Loss of plant life in Port Hills shown in satellite images
thread.title_full: Loss of plant life in Port Hills shown in satellite images

author: Shar Davis
title: Loss of plant life in Port Hills shown in satellite images
text:
Loss of plant life in Port Hills shown in satellite images SHAR DAVIS Last updated 11:53, February 23 2017 Deimos Imaging 
A satellite image of Christchurch's Port Hills taken on Monday, February 20, 2017. The red indicates levels of clorophyll, and compared to a similar image from September 2015, shows large losses of plant life from the recent fires, with burned areas showing as black or grey. 
Satellite pictures show the extent of damage caused by the fires that raged in the Port Hills. 
The images, released by Spanish company Deimos Imaging, show vegetation levels on Monday and September, 2015. 
READ MORE: The Port Hill fires, which started on February 13, ripped through about 2075 hectares. About 450 houses were evacuated, nine homes destroyed and two partially damaged. A state of emergency was declared on February 15. Deimos Imaging 
A September 2015 satellite image gives a baseline of plant life in the Port Hills, with chlorophyll levels shown as a shades of red. 
Vegetation appears red in the images, captured by the company's satellite, Deimos-2. 
"Different shades of red provide crucial information on chlorophyll content and plants' health," a spokeswoman from Deimos Imaging said. 
The image after the fires clearly shows a large level of loss to the Port Hills with many areas now black or grey. Charlie Gates 
A flythrough showing the impact of the Port Hills fire in Christchurch. 
The satellite was launched in 2014 and is the"highest-resolution fully private satellite in Europe," she said.
